clinical_study.official_title: Finding the Latent Treponema Pallidum of Syphilis With Serofast Status

brief_summary.textblock: Some syphilitic patients remain in a serologically positive state after the recommended therapy. Whether a serofast state could represent a persistent low-level infection by Treponema pallidum is still unknown. The possibility that persistent nontreponemal antibodies after treatment represent persistence of Treponema pallidum was raised by some investigators. The investigators use the Next-Generation Sequencing to test blood plasma, srum, cerebrospinal fluid, aqueous humor, lymph nodes, skin lesion, saliva, semen,milk of serofast patient and other positive and negative controls.

detailed_description.textblock: Some syphilitic patients remain in a serologically positive state after the recommended therapy. Whether a serofast state could represent a persistent low-level infection by Treponema pallidum is still unknown. The possibility that persistent nontreponemal antibodies after treatment represent persistence of Treponema pallidum was raised by some investigators. The investigators use the Next-Generation Sequencing to test blood plasma, serum, cerebrospinal fluid, aqueous humor, lymph nodes, skin lesion, saliva, semen,milk of serofast patient and other positive and negative controls.

primary_outcome.description: Using the Next-Generation Sequencing to test specific genome of treponema pallidum for syphilis

arm_group.description: The syphilitic patients who remain in a serologically positive state after therapy

In the early syphilis patients, at 6 months following treatment, a serological cure was defined as either a negative RPR or ≥2 dilution (4-fold) decrease in the RPR titer. In the late syphilis patients, at 12 months following treatment, a serological cure was defined as either a negative RPR or ≥2 dilution (4-fold) decrease in the RPR titer.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All clinical diagnosis of syphilis cases
Exclusion Criteria:
- Auto-immune disease (such as SLE)
- Lyme disease
